div.head: EGYPTIAN MUMMIES ABOUT 1100 B.C.
div.p: In the last published report of l'Institnt Egyptiev, saga "The Lancet," there are two papers by medical men worthy of ateyna, tion. The institute was (founded in 1859 to carry on the litereitid scientific work for which 'Institut d'Egypte \Ivas origin-ally created by Napolon.ani_his-limous group of men of science during the. Frecch occupation of Egypt. Until about ten years ago English-men were very rarely admitted to the honour of membership for, in spite of the red coats at headquarters,France still remained in jealously guarded, intellectual occupation of Egypt. Now matters have somewhat changed and no less than eight English names. appear in the list of active members, the number of which is strjetly limited to 50. To the report under notice Dr. Bay contributes a paper on the electric pheno-mena that accompany the "khisausin" wind which in Arabia and Syria is called the "simoom" and bears the name of "sirocco" in Algiers and Sicily. The wind blows intermit-tently from the south during a period of about '50 days in March, April, and May. The heated air collies Straight from the desert charged with very fine dust and sand, ubscunug the sun and compelling people to shut up their houses as far as possible. Tile phenomenon usually lasts only three days, of which the second is the moat trying and reminds those exposed to it of the sensation 01 'standing near a furnace. During the khamain the earth, charged with negative electricity, hotda in equilibrium the positive electricity ut the atmosphere until at the close ut the phenomenon, generally accom-panied by a few drops ur showers ut lain, the electricity is changed, the air beouwiug negative and the ground wain ve. Meanwhile accidents sowitimes occur to the large machines which have receutty been constructed tar supplying electric light. Dr. U. Elliot Smith has been working tor three years at the investigatiou of embalming in the twenty-first dynasty, having been presented with 44 mummies of that period tor the anatomical department, of the Egyptian School of Medicine at Ulm°. These minimum were lomat at Demelthan in 12491. In spite of many authors, and wore contuotures, nobody knows exactly whets the ancient practice of embalming began. In pre-lustunc stays, more than 7,000 years ago, the inhabitants of Upper Egypt exposed their dead to a sun-dry-ing process which has preserved them until to-day. It is suggested that so long ago as the titth dynasty the pyramid builders nude( use of artificial means to resist the nature' -decay of the dead body, but there is no certainty as to what they did. The Cairo Museum shows, by its unique collection ot,niuminiea, that real utuuniticatiun, aided by art, belongs to the period between the seventeenth dynastyand the early days of the sixth century of the Christian era Dr.. Elliot Smith rewinds us that tithing this period ot about 2,000 y the methuths ot embalming' underivent changes. From the eighteenth to the twentieth dynasties the tuethodsiadopted consisted only in the preservation' of\the body and as everyone knows who has seenite Royal Ramo-side mummies this was accomplished so successfully that the nixie employed can will have beeu the result ofcenturnas of experiment. About the begiuuing ot the twenty-first dynasty (a period ut decline, when Egypt was being menaced by victotiuus Assyria) the embalmers initiated a new practice which was an attempt to restore to the shrunken body the form which it had lost during. the (tarty stages ot embalming ; this was dune by packing under the skin and in the cavities linen, sawdust, sand, and other materials.

div.head: New Year Greetings to all our Readers
Weekly Gold Return
div.p: The import of coin between the 21st and 28th inst. totalled L.E 179,932 and the export was L E. 98.

div.head: Cairo's New Bridges
div.p: The slight alterations which were fonnd to be necessary on the small bridge at Rodah being now practically complete, the Rodah bridges will be formally opened for traffic some time in the coming month.

div.head: An Interesting Case
div.p: The action" against the Egyptian Government for wrongful dismissal, which is being brought by Mr. Albert Simha, late Chief Store-keeper of the Ports and Lights Administration at Alexandria, will not be heard until February next.

div.head: The Tour Eiffel
div.p: The performance at the Tour Eiffel keeps up its standard of excellence and is quite deserving of a good attendance. The debut of "Gimps Zingara et son chanteur" was very warmly applauded, and provided turns of Spanish songs and dances of quite exceptional merit.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: The modern day wonder Fregoli, ,whose impersonations are creating so much content in Alexandria, will give a matinee performance at the Alhambra Theatre tomorrow afternoon. His programme is continually being changed and, as an artist of the highest class, he commands large audiences, which are always most enthusiastic in their applause.

div.head: Tales of Modern Egypt
div.p: On page 5, of today's issue we publish an-other tale by ”Madge Hoole." It has been suggested that we should republish the whole collection if these stories as a small booklet. We should be' very pleased' to consider the matter of any correspondent would inform us as to the dates when the first stories were published in our columns a few years ago.

div.head: Sidi Sarrani Station
div.p: The increase in the ordinary expenditure of the Coastguard Administration to L. E. 141‘839 as against L E. 129,504 in 1907 is in the main due to the establishment of a station at Sidi Barrani, with a view to enable the Coastguard Administration to petrol the adjacent portion of the Mediterranean coast.

div.head: Cholera Scare
div.p: The rumour which was sent round Alexandria yesterday afternoon that a case of Cholera had occurred at Mex is absolutely untrue. On Sunday a Frenph vessel from Kayak reported 9 cases, of which 7 fatal, on arrival at Pert -Said. The stritest regulations were °Mowed to render any communication With the shore impossible, and the vessel was sent through the Canal ender guard.

div.head: Protecting the Sudan
div.p: Owing to the cholera having reached the Hedjaz the Sudan Government authorities are taking precaution to guard the coast and prevent Clandestine disembarkation A sufficient force of mounted police liaa been appointed for this purpose, as was done last year., It is hoped that these active measures will succeed in warding off the introduction of the plague into that country.

div.head: Evangelism at Khartoum
div.p: A commission of the Synod of the Evangelical Church, of Egyptias arrived at for the purpose of organizing a church, and laying the foundation of the church building which will be erected at Khartoum. A meeting of the Church membership was held on Friday week for the election of elders and deacons, who will be installed next Monday evening. The ceremony of laying the foundation of the Church building will take place on Monday afternoon.

div.head:
THE LATE REV. D. P. MILLER
THE INQUEST
div.p: The inquest into the circumstances under which the Rev D. P. Miller met his death was held by the British Consul at Cairo yester day. Dr. Madden and Major Hardy gave evidence as to being called to the pharmacy to which Mr. Miller had been conveyed and to attending him. The evidence of three Europeans and the, tram conductors went to show that' the motorcar, which was the cause of the accident, followed tile tram for- some distance at a normal rate on the way to the garage. The chauffeur, a Greek, after confirming, this evidence, said that Ise applied the brake as soon ail he saw the shadow thrown by the deceased in front of him but it was too late and Mr. Miller fell under the car. Private Davy, of the Ordnance Office, gave evidence to attending the injured man in the first instance and of obtaining 'assistance, the Consul thank. ing him for the prompt manner in which he had acted. Captain Jarvis, of the police; hav-ing given technical evidence as to the car and the distance from the train at which it was travelling, the jury after retiring for five minutes returned a verdict of "accidental death" and exonerated the chauffeur of the car to blame.

div.head: LONDON TURKISH AMBASSADOR
div.p: APPOINTMENT OF A MOSLEM
(Gazette's Special Service)
London, Tuesday

It is reported that Hakki Bey, the well-known legal advisor to the Porte and who is a Mohamedan, will be appointed Turkish Ambassador at London. The Mohamedan officials of the Porte have for long been agitating for a Mohamed ambassador in view of the large number of Moslems in the British Empire.

div.head:
THE BRITISH NAVY
NEW GIANT BATTLESHIPS
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service)
London, Tuesday

The first keel of the new, '`Dreadnought" class of battleship, to be named "St. Vincent," has been laid down at Poitsmouth. The vessel will have a displacement of 19,200 tons The order is officially confirmed to build the battle-ship "Rodney" with a displacement of20,000 tons. Vickers Maxim liavis received the order for the armament of these battleships.

div.head: SUSPENSION OF CORN DUTIES
div.p: London, Tuesday
The British ambasssdor at Constantinople notifies that the corn import duties for Salonica, Afonaster, and Kossovo vilayeta have been suspended for a period of two months at most,

div.head: THE DRUCE CASE
div.p: (Gazette's Special Serice)
London, Tuesday

The claimant's solicitor statest bat the Druce perjury charge will be pursued, and asserts that the body found in the Druce grave at Highgate cemetery must be proved to be the corpse of Mr. T.C. Druce.
The general opinion is, however, that the case will no fall to the ground. .

div.head: PILGRIM STEAMER STRANDED
div.p: (Gazette's Special Serice)
London, Tuesday
The Russian steamer "Gregory Morch" with 1,900 pilgrims on board has stranded on a reef at Abon Framish, thirty miles orth of Jeddah .

div.head: A CHRISTMAS DINNER
div.p: Messrs George Jennings Ltd. who have for-some time put been engaged in connection with the "drainage and sanitation of the net, Government residences at Getireb, entertained their English staff at dinner on Christmas day, in the employes meas-room; seasonably decorated for the occasion, where the guests; to the number of eighteen, dill ample justice to the excellence of the repast provided, at the con-clusion of which, and after the usual loyal toasts had been submittefl and duly honoured, the chairman, Mr. S. Jennings, proposed the health of the inain,drainage.department of the Public Works Ministry coupled with the name of its respected controller general, Mr. C. Carkeet James,the expertengineer under whose administration and able ;direction the recent labors of the firm in enunection with this initial work of public drainage in Cairo, bad been conducted and brought to so satisfactory a conclusion, which augured well for the tufure success of the vast scheme of Cairo drainage upon which he was engaged, — a scheme so essentially identified with the public health, and the continued development and prosper-ity of the city.

The "prosperity of the firm" and other "healths".and "sentiments" having been pro-posed, cordially received,and suitably acknowledged, a subsequent smoking conoert materially contributed to the success of the enter-tainment, which was proneunced an unqualified success.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. "Kaffir Prince," with general cargo left Malta yesterday and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Friday the 3rd January.

div.head: THE NEW GREAT PASS
div.p: INAUGUARATED YESTERDAY
Yesterday the new Great Pass to Alexandria harbour was 4icially inaugurated by Rear-Admiral Sir R. Massie Blomfield, the inaugura-tion being attended with full pomp and ceremony.

At noon all the Government vessels in harbour and H.M.S. "Diana" (Capt. Heatheost Grant) dressed ship, taking their time from the yacht "Cuhona" of Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan, who repreFented the Khedive.

From 2.30 to 3 p.m. those invited to attend the inauguration boarded the "Cuhona," the "Aida," std the "Diana." On board the "Cuhona" the Consular Corps and ' Heads of Departments were received by the Prince ; the 1 guests of the Admiral wore entertained aboard the "Aida," and on the "Diana" Captain Heathcoat Grant received the ladies and those friends whom officialdom did not invite.

Punctually at 3 p m the Khedivial Standard was broken on board the "Cuhona," and was immediately saluted by the guns of the German training ship "Freya" and then by H.M.S "Diana." The "Cuhona" then got under wehig and, followed by the "Diana," "Aida'' and "Ab-bas," proceeded to the harbour entrance, where they all dropped anchor under the breakwater.

Owing to the heavy weather the original programme of inauguration was not strictly adhered to, but, despite the angry seas, Prince Aziz, Rear Admiral Sir Massie El/infield, Sheehan Bey, and Mr. Girard (French Consul) boarded the pilot tug "Etaif' and, passing out and in through the new Orest Pass, officially inaugurated it.

On the return of the " Etaif " to the calmer. waters of the harbour, the "Diana" thundered ou t another royal salute to declare that the pass was- open.The "Abbas" and "Teir el Mina" next proceeded through the pass and aboard the latterwereGyafton Bey,chief engineer, and Mr. Gardner, dredger master, under whose techni-cal directions the new- lighthouse has been built and the pass dredged. On the return of "Etaif" all the vessels which bad taken part in the ceremony returned to their moorings. Captain Heathcoat Grant then paid an official visit to H.H. Prince Ant aboard the "Cu hona" and the Prince on returning the visit shortly after sundown, was greeted with a salute of 21 guns.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive will not hold a reception on Accession Day owing to its proximity to Courban Beyram, which falls on the 14th January.
Persons, who desire to put their names on the register on Accession Day can do so at the ceremonies office, Abdin Palace.
The fifth list of subscriptions for the Rhea divial Accession Fete amounts to L.E. 918 and 325 milliemes.

The Khedive received the following persons in audience ott Friday last, Baron Gaiffier d'Hestroy, Diplomatic Agent for Belgium, who presented Baron Deacampq, and Mr. Carton de Wiart ; Mr. Wells, Inspector General of Mines, who took leave of his Highness ; Mr. Paul Harvey ; Prince Kernel Fadel Pasha , Prince Haidar Fadel Pasha ; Baron Empain ; and Mr. R. Said Ruete. On Saturday morning his Highness received the Grand Cadi of Egypt and Mr. G.P Graham, who thanked the Khedive for his promotion to the post of Director-General to the Department of Public Health.

div.head: COMPANY PROCEDURE IN EGYPT
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

'Dear Sir, — The following article is comprised in the "Articles of Association" of a Limited Liability Company pronibted and foisted on the public of Egypt and London some few years ago. It is almost needless to state that this Company has turned ont to be a bilge fiasco, if not gorse. 'Nevertheless, I shall be glad if your readers, many of them directors of companies domiciled in London, but having Egypt for their base of operations would kindly inform me if such an article is imposed aq a usual and customary condition ender which shareholders are invited to subscribe capital for Joint Stock Companies.

92.— Tout ce qui aura Etafo fait par une As-seiiiblee du Conseil ou d'un Comae de Conseil, ou tau quelqu'un agissant comme Administra-teur,-quand aneme it wait reconnu plus tard y' avast eu nomination do dit Administra-teur on .de la personne agissant comma Administmteur, ou memo s'ils n'avaient pas qualite pour agir, sera ausi valsble quo si toutes coy personnel avaient 0.4 dArnent nom-mdes et avaient en qualite pour occuper le poste d'Administmteur.

Under the above it would seem that an enterprising boab might run the whole show and having collected the shareholders money in every available direction quietly decamps with the connivance, say of the Managing Director, and share the proceeds with him and no blame attaches to any one.

If people who may be about to subscribe capital to public companies would only take the trouble to read the published articles of association they might in some cases save their money—I don't say they would neces-sarily save it, having regard to the facility with which dishonest directors wreck bunt fide concerns here, and escape with impunity, but if a little precaution were taken, andsome few pre-liminary enquiries made, shareholders would less frequently give their support to rotten concerns of which we have had so many instances in Egypt lately.
Yours faithfully,

div.head: CAIRO WATER COMMISSION
div.p: THE SOURCE OF IMPURITIES

The report of the Cairo Water Commission, is, in so far as the actual analysis of the water inpply of Cairo is 'concerned, of a very satisfactory nature, as will be seen from one of the =eluding sentences of the report, which runs is 'follows "In brief, apart from the possible aresence of undesirable bacteria, there nothing in the composition of the cater which is capable of giving rise to sickness or disease. It is true that in in earlier paragraph it is stated that the mem-)(ors of the commission are not satisfied that he water supply is entirely satisfactory but ..he difficulties in the way of destroying such impurities as exist in the water, and in re-medying the causes which are said to conduce 10 this opinion do not appear to be very great, the water bearing s trata at Rod-el Farag, affords in the opinion of the commission a eery good filter, and the presence of a small mount of iron and manganese in the water ire the only defects in its chemical composition. These will, however, require to be remov-.K1, and the commission suggests that systematic experiments should be carried out in order to ascertain the best and cheapest method of accomplishing this, and there are several other points in connection with the working Itc. of the wells which are also brought forward is being in need of greater attention than is it present accorded to them.

The method of adding aluminium sulphate o the water entering the settling tanks of the Ghizeh supply by the judgnent of the naked :ye alone is condemned, it being considered necessary to introduce the use of apparatus to ceurately measure the turbidity of the water, both previous to and after settling, and the lecessity of absolute cleanliness in dealing cith the sand on the filters is urged by the commission, who also offer many other sus cestions of a technical nature applicable alike o the Ghiteh and Abbassia supplies. In regard to the latter it is stated that the present intake s in an unsatisfactory position and should be come distance from the town, while the practice )f mixing water from this supply with that of Rod-el-Farag is condemned.

With regard to the system of distribution the commission points out that this is largely in engineering matter and with the exception perhaps of the suggestion that the mains ohould he laid at a greater depth than at aresent there is nothingjncluded in the report which would not occur to the mind of any modern engineer. It will be necessary, if the !ommission is to be followed by any beneficial Teults for the authorities to take the suggested niiirovements and alterations immediately in land, as it is of little vane possessing a water 'apply which is chemically pure, if impurities ire to creep in through a faulty system of listribution, and it would seem that there is argent need of alterations in that which at sresent exists, and now that the purity of the water at its source has been assured io time should be lostin perfecting the system of supply. It is, as pointed out in the report, difficult owing to the lack of any drainage oyster; to flush out dead-ends where they exist it the poorer quarters and we trust that something definite as to the much-talked-of irainage scheme may be done immediately.

The scheme is, we believe, one which will put Jairo on a sanitary basis equal to that of any nodern town, and as this will possibly be a cork which will occupy years in its accomplish-nent, it is of the utmost importance that the .ping should be pushed through with the great-$t possible di 'patch. We had hoped that the rear 1907 would have witnessed the conclusion of the preliminaries, but as this is now impoe-ible, we can only trust that the authorities will make up for log time in the coming year, aid that the summer may find the work well in land. Many of thostiggestions embodied in the port of the commission appear to be almost in-necessary at first sight, but it is to obese imall things that many of our European cities swe their sanitary reputation and the commis-ion were wise in insisting upon absolute clean-ineas in the work, no less than upon the eli-nination of chemical impurities from the water-thelf.

div.head: WADY KOM OMBO CO
div.p: At a meeting at Cairo of the Wady Kom Ombo Company, which was held on Monday afternoon and at which 207,000 shares were represented, it was resolved on the proposition of the Chairman, M. Snares, that 21,000 feddans of land being now quite, ready for tgricultural purposes, it would be in the nterests of the Company to confine their operations for the present principally to the levelopment of this land in order to ascertain ghat the yield would be worth, and to proceed with the work of reclaiming other land to igriculture slowly and as opportunity present-id itself. It was also resolved to alter the late of the issue of the balance sheet from July 31st to December 31st. Mr. Walter lorachitz was duly elected to fill the place on he Board left vacant by Sir Elwin Palmer.

The crops for the past year were pronounced :0 have been very satisfactory, and the working of the new pumps had also given every satis action. A balance sheet and report giving full total's of the work of the company will be aublished in a few days.

div.head: NOTICE TO OUR READERS
div.p: Tomorrow being New Year's Day, the "Egyptian Gazette" will not be published.
K.S.C.
POLO MATCHES
On Saturday last two very good matches were played at Ghezireh :-

It was soon apparent the E. A. were out-classed in ponies, and Capt. Harvey had the misfortune to injure his hand half way through the game. The IC.S.0 team won by 6 goals to love. Three of these were scored by Sei ffou Bah Yousry Pasha, whose shooting at goal was very accurate. Mr. Heller seems to have im-proved in his polo and to observe the rules of the game more closely.

This was a most exciting match, very accurate polo being played, and the ground seemed to be in excellent condition. Mr. Evans at No. 1, kept Major Haig, his back, galloping for his strokes, this had a good deal to do with the result of the game Mr. Bowen, Capt Bartlett., and Mr. Schreiber's team lost the first two goals but eventually won by 5 goals to 2. There was a large gathering of spectators watching the match.
First ebukker The Dragoons seemed to have rather the best of it, Mr. Schreiber saving his goal several times : Major Ansell scored the first goal for his side just as the' bell rang.

Second chukker. From the throw in Mr. Bowen, who is beautifully mounted, came away with the ball and scored a splendid goal with a long high shot. Shortly after this Capt. Bartlett dribbled the ball through from a serimago near goal. Score. Reda.1 goal. Whites 2 goals. Major Haigs pony shying off the ball, let in Capt. Bartlett who again scored. Score two all.

Third chukker. After this there was some even play until rapt. Bartlett who was playing beautifully scored again. Reda. 3. Whites 2. Mr. Seymour was the next to score a good centreing back hander giving him nice opening. Score Reds 4. Whites 2.
Fourth chukker. Mr. Schreiber was conspicuous his defence being very round, and his back handers all "coming through". The last goal was scored by Mr. Seymour with a very clover back hand shot.
FINAL SCORE
Major Haig's team 2 goals
Mr. Schreiber's team 5 goals

div.head:
GOLF
BOGEY COMPETITION
div.p: A Golf Competition was played at Ghezireh on the 25th and 26th inst. Scores as below ; Mr. R. Hamilton and Mr. N. G. Colman were equal for first place .—

Jedda was lately the scene of great rommo-tion owing to the occurrence of,a destructive fire in one of its principal bazaars. The outbreak was in the khasikiah street which is covered with arcades of planks. Many shops, have been destroyed, the fire having raged for some hours before it could be got under control. The origin of the fire and the damages are not exactly known, but bazaar rumour estimates the damage at one laid' of dollars. It is a great pity that in spite of the liability of buildings to catch fire in these parts there is not a proper fire-engine to check the conflagration on the occurrence of a fire. The want of such an engine is more particularly felt at liodeida, whore a recent fire destroyed more than a hundred huts, nearly half of Hodeida being made up of huts.

The steamers "Rahmani" and "Shaltlim" passed here on the 16th and 17th inst. from Bombay en route to Jeddah with 788 and 697 respectively. The steamers "Shahs hum" and "Zabinghla" also passed here from Bombay on route to Jeddah with a contingent of pilgrims.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Sir Rudolph von Slatin Psalm has arrived at Singo, on his tour of inspection and is due back at Khartom very soon.
Sir Auckland Colvin, who some days ago was seriously ill, is now progressing favourably towards recovery.
The will of the late Judge Hills formerly of the Mixed Appeal Court, Alexandria, has been proved at 5,038 7s 5d.
It is rumoured that Miralai Wilson Rey, the Governor of Semler Province will sowed Miralai Stanton Bey, as Governor of Khartoum, after the retirement of Stanton Bey, within about a year's time.
Mr. G. H. Faber, M.P. for Boston, sailed on Friday by the P. and 0. steamer "Britannia" for Port Said on a visit to Egypt. He will be accompanied by Mrs. Faber and his daughter, Mrs Kelman.

The Belgian Royal Geographitial Society at Antwerp bas conferred its gold medal upon Lieutenant Boyd Alexander, who read a payer before the society on Thursday evening, deScribing his journey acmes Africa from the Niger to Lake Triad and thence to the Nile.
The death occurred on the 24th inst. at Jerusalem of Mr. Antoine Morcos at the age of 68 years. He was for many years proprietor of the Grand Hotel at Jerusalem.

div.head: EGYPT'S POSTAL SERVICE
div.p: The ordinary expenditure for 1908 has been fixed at LB. 259;798 as against L.E. 239,498 in 1907. This increase of L g. 20,300 is chiefly required for strengthening the staff to cope with increased work and to meet the increased cost of transport, rents, etc. Receipts for 1907, estimated at L.E. 260,000, will approx-imately roach L K 295,000. Those for 1908 are estimated at L.E. 280,000. The total number of letters exchanged with Great Britain and her Colonies in 1907 will probably attain 3,571,000 as against 2,692,500 in 1906, an increase of over 30%. Sineerthk reduction in December 1901 of the cost of Post-age from 10 to 5 millimes, the gross increase in the number of letters despatched to these countries is 107 %, or, after dikincting the probable increase based on chi normal growth of preceding years, 77 %, which must be re-garded as extremely satisfactory.

A similar reduiftion in postage with Italy came into force in July 1'06 with the result that the number of letters exchanged in 1907 amounts apprtiximately to 1,191,000 as against 815,200 last year, being an increase of 46 %. The Suction in the price of inland post-cards from 3 to 2 milliemes has been attended with the happiest results. Approximately 2,000,000 cards have been sent this year as against 1,185,000 in 1906; the loss in revenue has therefore easily been covered.

The number of depositors in the Savings Bank shows an increase of 12,666 to the end of October and now exceeds 71,000. Although for the first time in its history the monthly with-drawals have on three occasions exceeded the deposits, there still remains an increase on the first ten months of L. E. 42,135. The total amount now on deposit is L. E. 373,207. Al though these figures oboe a gratifying increase, it must be admitted with regret that the Savings Bank can hardly be said as yet to have achieved complete success as a popular institution.
The number of British postal orders issued amounts to 27,500 for the first ten months of 1907, as against 21,000 for the whole of 1906.

Admiral Philibert has been promoted a Grand Officer of the Legion of Honour. (Havas)
M. Pichon will to advantage of the holidays to visit the Minister for Foreign Affairs at Madrid. (Havas)
M. Pichon is going to Madrid to return the visit of the Spanish Minister for Foreign Affairs (Reuter)
The troops will leave today. They will advance towards Taghert from three sides (Havas)
The appointment of General Damade is regarded as signifying a more active military policy in the Casablanca region, similar to General Lyautey's operations on the Algero-Moroccan frontier. (Reuter)

div.head: THE COFFIN OPENED
div.p: The Druce coffin has been opened. It contains the body of an aged bearded man. This is regarded as disposing of the pretensions of the claimant to the Dukedom of Portland (Reuter)
The "St. Vincent," an improved type and 1,350 tons larger than the "Dreadnought," has been laid down at Portsmouth. (Reuter)
While the violinist Ysaye was playing at a concert here, his reserve Stradivarius, valued between 2,000 and 3,000, was stolen. (Reuter)

div.head: THE AMERICAN CRISIS
div.p: A TERRIBLE SITUATION
The homeless and unemployed here are estimated at 100,000; charity institutions are overwhelmed. (Reuter)
President Fallieres has pardoned or reduced the sentences on 474 military offenders on the occasion of the New Year. (Reuter)

div.head: GHIZEH GARDENS
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir,—Who is responsible for the present state of the Ghizeh Gardens? Its changed condition, however, makes our hearts sad. There has been a ruthless destruction; of trees. Some of the finest have been cut down and for what reason do you imagine? To create a kitchen, garden; for the whole plus is little else now. Peas and potatoes are all very well in their way ;1. but to destroy our only spacious and umbrageous garden for their cultivation an act of vandalism in comparison with the removal, of an ancient monument or "modernia, ea" restoration is a trifling peccidilo. Though the Ghizeh grounds are now beautifully laid out for the growing of vegetable, the roads are neglected and one placed next to the ruins of a conservatory there is a thole i many feet deep without any protection. Indeed it is generally filled with water so as, presumably, to render it less easily visible. Cairo is pone too healthy as the weekly statistics fully ,fostify ; and to have destroyed this, its single lung, which used to be the resort on fete days of thousands of tired town-workers, is an offence for which the authorities ought to be held criminally responsible or at least be punished with dismissal. What can be the attitude of minds of people who, in a tropical coun-try, callously order the whole sale demolition of trees- in the vicinity of the capital it is hard to conceive. Lovers of nature they can-not be, still less lovers of their kind. Doubtless they are accustomed to look upon the native Egyptian as barbarous, But surely the barbarian who gave to 'Cairo this garden was more civilized than those who have ruined it.
I am, Sir., Whirs, etc.

div.head: MODERN EGYPT.
div.p: BY LORD CROMER
The following are extracts from the introduc-tory chapter to Lord Cromer's book "Modern Egypt"
My object in writing this book is twofold:
In the first place, I wish to place on record an accurate narrative of some of the principal events which have occurred in Egypt,and in the Sudan since the year 1876:*
In the second place, I wish to explain the results which have accrued to Egypt from the British 'occupation of the country in 1882.

The accidents of my public life have afford-ed me special opportunities for compiling certain 'chapters of Egyptian history. From March 1877 to June 1880, and ogain from September 1883 up to the present time (1907), I have been behind the scenes of Egyptian affairs. Besides those sources of information which are open to all the world, I have had access to all the dot:meats in the archives of the Foreign Offices of both London and Cairo, and I have been in close communication with, I think, almost every one who has taken a leading part in Egyptian affairs during the period the history of which I have attempted to write. Thus, I think, I may fairly lay claim to be in a position of exceptional advantage in so far as the attainment of accuracy is concerned.
On March 23, 1876, Mr. Stephen Cave, Who had been sent to Cairo, to report on the finan-cial condition of Egypt, expressed himself in the following terms:

"Egypt.may be said to be in a transition state, and she suffers from the defects of the sys-tem out of which she is passing, as well as from those of the system into which she is attemp-ling to enter. She suffers from the ignorance, dishonesty,waste, and extravagance of the East, such as have 'nought her suzerain to the verge of ruin, and at the same tithe from the vast expense caused by hasty and inconsiderate en-deavours to adopt the civilisation of the West.'

An attempt will be made in the following pages to give some account of the measures adopted since Mr. Cave wrote his report, to arrest, as I hope aini would fain believe, to re-medy the disease, whose main features are des-cribed with accuracy in the passage quoted above.

I trust that such an account will notbe de. void of interest to the general reader, and that it will be of some special interest to those of thy fellow-countrymen who are, or who at some future time may be engaged in Oriental-adminis-tration. It is to this latter class that I would more especially address myself, for they can appreciate the nature of the problems which have presented themselVes for solution, and the difficulty of solving them, more fully than those who are devoid of special administrative experience in the East.

The history of reform in Egypt does not present any striking feature-to which some analogy might not perhaps found in otter coun-tries where European et isation has, in a greater or less defree has been grafted on a backward Eastern government and society.
But, so far as I am aware, no counterpart can be found to the special circumstances which have attended the work of Egyptian reform. Those circumstances have, in truth, been very' peculiar.

In the first place, onkalien race. the English, have had to control antguide a second alien race, the Turks, by whom they were dislike in the government of a third race, the Egyptians. To then latter, }loth the paramount race-4 are to a certain extent unsympathetic.. In the case of the Turks, the want Of sympathy fiss been mitigated by haspit, by a common religion, and by the use of a common fang age In the case of the English, it has been mitigated by the respect due to superior talents, and by the be-nefits which- hau) accrued to the population from British interference.)

In the second place, it is to be observed that for diplomatic and other reasons, on which it is unnecessary for the moment to dwell, the Egyptian administration had to be reformed without any organic changes being effected in the conditions under which the government had been condneted prior to the British occupation.

It is, indeed, certain that whatever success has crowned the efforts ofieformeikin Egypt has been attained, not in virtue of the system, but in spite of it Those who hold, with the English poet, that "Snatcher is best admi-nistered is best," may perhaps find some co robcration for their theory in the recent histo-ry of Egypt. An experiment under somewhat novel conditions has, in tact, been made in Eastern administration, and, in spite of many shortcomings, this experiment has been crown-ed with a certain degree of success. It is this which gives to Egyptian reform its chief claim to the interest of the political student.
I have lived too long in the East not to be aware that it is difficult for any European to arrive at a true estimate of Oriental wishes, aspirations, and opinions.

I was for some while in 'Egypt before I fully realised how little I understood my subject ; and I found, to the last day of mriesidence in the country, that I was _constantly learning something. new. No casual visitor can hope to obtain much real insight into the true state of native opinion. Divergence of religion and habits of thought : in my own case ignorance of the vernacular language ; the reticence of

I have dealt fully and uureservedly with the whole of the principal historical events which occurred in Egypt from 1876 up to the time of Tewtik PaOtage, death (.Jamitiry 7. 18412) ; also with Sudan history up to the end or 1907. It, would, la my opinion., -.);* premature to deal -similarly with events in 110i,pt subbequent to the accession of the present Khedive.

Orientals when speaking to anyone in authority ; theyejacieuiyitosite nith any one toi whom they may be talking ; the want of mental symmetry and precision, which is the chief distinguishing feature between the illogical and picturesque East and the logical West, and which lends such peculiar interest to the study of Eastern life and politics ; the fact that religion enters to a greater .extent than in Europe into the social life and laws and customs of the people ;, and the further fact that the European and the Oriental, reasoning from the same premises, will often arrive at diametrically opposite conclusious,—all these facts place the European at a great disadvantage when he attempts.. to gauge .Eastern opinion. . . . On the whole, though I should not like to dogmatise on the spbject, I am inclined to think that by constantly seeing people of all classes, and by checking the information received from different sources, a fair idea of native opinion in Egypt may in time be formed:

I would add that it is not possible to live so long as I have lived in Egypt without acquiring a deep sympathy for the Egyptian people. The cause of Egyptian reform is one in which I take the warmest personal interest.

div.head: TALES OF MODERN EGYPT
div.p: RUDE BOREAS AND GENTLE ZEPHYR
AN INTERMEZZO BY MADGE HOOLE

That the pen is mightier than thesword is so trite a remark that an apology is due to my readers for mentioning such a subject. Whole quarries of slates have been filled with essays n this theme in board schools and other places here thechild of the working man is taught to be a nuisance to himself and a Curie to his country. Yet I am still of opinion that the last word has not been said in pods* of the pen, in proof of which I give the folloling points to the cunsidetion of the world - in general Firstly, you can only kill a man bow with a sword and not always that, if the sword happens to be made in England, whereas with a pen you can continuo to attack him before and after death, uutil iuk and grammar fail, or indeed past the latter point, to judge by certain journalistic efforts of the present day. Secondly, with a sword you,can only attack a man,by himself, whereas with a pep you can scarify, not only him, but also his relations up to the ninth aunt, thirdly, you cannot kill anyone with a sword unless you can pane to close range, eheted distance makes no differce once to an attack. with the pen, in fact, some of the most noted exponents of the art., prefer a "safety toile" between themselves and the person attacked. Lastly, to give two military examples,- na sword. ,ever forged.. succeeded.. in anniliihaing an entire jirmy at one blow, whereas- this.surprising feat has just been accomplished by the pen in our own happy isles; and many a General has got himself ifito a greater mess with the.pen. than he ever did with die sword, and I cannot say more than that. Having, I hope, strengthened the read ers belief in ' this hoary example of - the "crawbo repetita," I will' now proceed to give a local example of the teeth of my first tate-went. There existed a few years ago, in a certain- locality which I need not particularise, further; a man who exercised the ancient and lucrative profession of a brigand. It is more than doubtful if he had ever perused tee pages of John Jacques Rousseau, but in prat tree he carried out his theory that "all property . is robbery", to great perfection. In accordance withithesetenets, he placed himself in pokes. sion of Other 'people's property, as frequently-and as unostentatiously as possible. The exi-getioes of- his profession occasionally obliged him to kill as well as rob, whether this is blame-. able or`not depends-to a remarkable degree on sartorial .details. It has been noticed that those who kill in a blue coat with red patches on it,) 10 not 1 generally attain a very elevated losition in life, to those, on die otherhand: who do their Slaying in a red coat with blue patches on it, the highest prizes of life are open The brigand in ques-tion, made a epeciality of removing cattle, and hid, at the time of which I speak, carried out his socialistic theories so thoroughly, that the inhabitants of the district placked up their courage and complained to tbe Mudirieh. The latter, justly annoyed at this replied firstly, that they bad not been stolen. The inhabitants then approached the.Bash-katib in the way in which Bash katibs are' ' best approached,, and finally some ieeffec-teal stops. were taken. It is perhaps_ not greatly to be, wondered at that the steps taken were ineffectual, seeing that the police generally p9rsued their inquiries in the spirit of Doh errs and Verges; and whenever they wished to "apprehend a rogue," - and "lie - would not stand," presently "called the watch together", Egyptire woke up the gaffirs, and , "thanked' God they were. rid of a rogue." It will be remembered that I am speaking of ancient days, when the Acadhnie Abd el:Aziz, or the "Slop's Sandhurst," did not exist to furnish us *with those stalwart Itufe in blue, at once the , admiration of the tourist, and the terror of the malefactor. Rendered desperate by continued riti,i1g, the inhabitants despatched a complui9rto Cairo, to see whether that would have auy effect The Government at once came to their assistance, and sent out a circular on tle s ubject. 'the brigand, as a "countercheck quarrelsome," Made another raid and carried of more cattle. t he Government, in their, tuns gave the' "retort courteous" by issuing ameed-mental° their previous circular, and ordered it return to be prepared,. showing the amount of cattle carried off. Donkeys were to be shown Separately under the beading of "observations." The brigand, quite undisturbethby these severe measures, of which indeed Ale was quite un-aware, still persisted in stealing cattle. The Gpvernment then lane a proclamation-to the Mudirieh to the effect that the brigand was a "dangerous, inconvenient, and insaltibrious . establishment," and was to be closed at once. The Mudirieh replied with humility that t were ready and willing to,close the brigand', but that he persistently.- and feloniously ab-stained from being caught Various Omdebs arrested each other's relation, as a mark of good faith, but as they were too numerous to be the real "Simon Pure", not much good was done. After the unwinding of numerous spools of red-tape, and the exchange of several sacks of ungrammatiel correspondence between the Offices concern, the supply of seizable cattle ip the neighbourhood gave ont,and the brigand betook himself to fresh ',asthma, while. the Government leant back in its easy their, and announced that public order had been restored( What the -complainants thought of .the matter, deponent sayeth not, history rarely conde.s. cending to such petty details, which indeed would spoil the'moml perspective and disturb the mental detachment of the real historian. At the same time as the events recorded above, there Heed a certain European, called Angos- tura Bitters. He was a native of the famous and historic country of taria, and was a perfect epitome of those s riking virt es, well known to be implanted in the b f all the sons of that happy elim He ad left his 1 native shores with the firm intention of spreading her fame, and incidentally making a fortune. He had been most sticcessful in strength-ening and intensifying $he opinion of the natives on the ninny ell ncies of his nation in general, and of himsel its particular, but ', fortune had not yet crown his efforts. Many times and oft had he tho ght to have:seized that illusive fowl, but she, ad always escaped, leaving him stranded with an unremunerative tail leather in his band. by a strict atten-tion to his own interests, generous toleration of his own failings, and steady resolve- to gain a handsome dividen on his virtues, all characteristics of the great minds of the age, should not have gained the reward they deserved, I must leave to those philosophers to explain who, tilling the moral fields of life with-the spade ofexperien lioutauch golden crops of knowledge i nto billing guides to Parnassus. The fact remained, however, that the passbook of Mons. Bi tars displayed that vacuum, said to .1.4 ab rrent to nature.Beyond his natural desire to gain wealth, he had now other and loftier otives to spur him on. At the small provincial town, where he carried on a clinique for the distribution of a-certain soothing medical reparation to those poor patients, who were u able to purchase in bulk, he had made the ac taaintance of a fair compatriote. Moved by Ali me higher feelings that induce us, drier the refining influence of hive, to display our better sine to the charm-er, he had dwelt, perps enduly, on his wealth aid opulm ce; whilst the lady, actuated by the same lofty ideals:, had dazzled her adaiirer's eyes with a halo of golden beami, and thus the blindness of real love descended. on them equally. It must be confessed that be pos-sessed wealth only in the sense that the angler possesses the fish in the river, when be has caught them? whilst six tickets in alocal lottery, tirranged by a benevolent society, with an eery limited sphere of nativity, the lady's sole treasure (except' herself), sca ely bore out the lady's state. As so in as his pharmaceutical lab over for the day, the happy laver trod the prim e path that leads to the Elysipm of watrim ny, and one after-noon, he ventured to cola himself. - Render. ed eloquent by love, and merely interrupting his passionate outburst I r one moment to inquire the price lot cot n from a passing Mend, he 'poured the fives ires of his affections atilt lady's feet which he was pleased to accept Their marriage followed, in din coma, and with it came the inusi disillusion-ment. They discovered 4 an early "date that thei only treasure they possessed was the tree-sure of their love, and that, alas 1, nnot be banked. A treatise on the tends passions would be out of data in a oral y as this claims to be, but the su rising discovenes made by both parties to the covenant soon after marriage can only be explained by the tact that we never can see ourselves as others -iee us. If we could, most inen and all women wntild,commit suicide( out f pity to their kind. Ns is an epigram, but t ere are only throe women in Egypt who wil understand it and none who will believe it Our Benedict in' jowl in his tenderest fee ings, and driven to distraction by the fact tat although it may not be necessary to live, 3 is always necessary to eat, cast allOat to find oine new and more promising road to fortune At last a chance presented itself, and this as the manner of it. Near the home of out riend, there lived a ; native, who is the Tertium Quid of my story. Originally possessing a wall inheritance, he had become rich by the si iple method of con! tinuing to live and allow is land to increase in value, until it was worth such as induced him to dispose of it. lie filially dit., posed of his land tw a cempany. and -then he was confronted kith the problem of what to do with the money. At first he intended to take the advice of the manager of the company to. whom he had sold the lindr and place the inoney_in a bank, but wit ho gathered from the bank manager, that f r from charging him* lorieeping his money, t y would pay him for so doing, he rushed out o the office, indignant at being made such fool, and ,finally deposited the cash in Inv only financial.ins. atitutice, in which ho had ing real confidence, the National Bank, or h le in the cellar. The money remained them fo some time, and he was happier than most investors, if he had only known it. Bank rates might rise and fall it like the barometer before gale, without affecting him, and be could keep an eye on his securities in a manner impossible even to the most cautions trustee, keeping watch and ward over the funds of his wart whom he hopes to marry. He happened, mover to be rather addicted S thoseinedical comforts, dispensed so kindly by Mons Bit rs, and while visit-ing his cliniqtie, and under the influence of a pectoral lozenge, had talked rather too openly of his wealth and even even thrown out some vague hints as to what it was deposited. Mons , Bitters/pricked-. p his ears. He did. i not see any imtnediate ad, antage to be pined by his knowledge, but yet; He made up ether prescription for his friend, "exhibiting " patience,' if not skill, and returned home thoughtful In most walks of Moak. the man comes home thoughtful, the woman at once suspects another-c6man ; when the wo-man comes home thoughtful, the man suspects another man, i.e. himself. This is a beautiful revisit of nature, and, holds good in all I climes and amongst all -tithes. Madame Bitters, then, in accordance with this universal rule, jumped to the concles4n that some other woman was .ccincerued, and as the happened to hate her husband, naturally bated the sup-positious woman worse for not bating him too. She happened to be wrong. There is a very old adage that great minds.think alike. Mons A. Bitters had a great mind and so had oarfriond the brigand. The latter in his search for fresh pastures in which to exorcise his talents, bad moved to the $411110 village inhabited by the other actors in- this tale Ile too was a client of Mons Bitters, and had the same desire to soothe his symptoms with the paregoric, before mentioned. He and the native therefore happened to meet at the "pharmacy," and listened to each other's rather loosely jointed converse tion. The details of the brigand's past did not interest the wive, but the details of the natives's present interested the brigand' very much indeed. He did not see any immediate advantage to be gained by his knowledge, but yet; It was here that the juncture of two powerful minds took place. The awns fond wish came simultaneously to the mind of the rude brigand, user of the sword, and to the mind of the cultured European, wielder of the pen. This may be accounted for by telepathy, by thought transference, or even by,:another motive. I will however no longer play with my readers, I will gives name to this !native, which actuated two such different persons, they _both desired to transfer)the native's banking account to their own credit. That they did so desire, may be to their credit or it may not ; that is no affair of mine, I Simply relate what happened, and the different methods each adopted to its ends. The brigand, after several conversations with the native, began to have a fairly clear idea of where the money was hidden. Once that was ascertained, the rest was plain sailing to a man of his profes-sional ability. The only thing that worried him was the exact amount of the money. If there was as m-Eich as he hoped, it would be impossible to remove it all without a con-federate, and 05 these- he had a wholesome dread. lie had had before now to "remove!' a confederate, because to his -simple- mind, distrust of the future actions of a past assistant was painful to his inner-feelings. On the other hand, if hehad to leave any money behind ha %could experience those poignant, feelings of regret., which fill the mind of the company-promoter, who has only got £50 out of the a idow, when he might have got .£100. At last he determined to go by himself, and trust to luck. He had not much fear of interruption. The house was in a lonely position, and as the local authorities, in that spirit of fair play that should obtain between governors and governed, invariably allowed it to be known in which direction the patrols were going, he did not wanrouolt. tliought on their movements ChoO-ing a night when he knew that the patrols were going in the opposite direction, he set outi with his gun and his burglar's housewife. Unfortunately for him, two events had taken place on which he had not reckoned. The:find was that Britannia had been seized with one of those fits of politic' flatulency, that occasionsaly afflict the old hialy, and had expressed a wish that the natives s.houla be taught to help themselves. I may mention that .thy brigand had been helping himself for year without any instruction, but this is by the way. The second was that an English inspector had come down to inspect. In accordance with the wishes' of Britannia, he was bent on helping the natives to help themselves, and considered that the best method was to catch any native he saw helping himself Ho therefore made the patrol go back ors their traces, and caught our friend creeping along with his gun and his bag of tools, which he was too taken by sur-prise to throw away. Utterly flabbergasted at his capture, he could make no valid defence, and was sentenced to a term of imprisonment as a suspicions character When released he had quite lost his nerves and his connections, met sank down to the position of "Tahsilgy" to the M infidel). Sword having thus failed utterly, let us see what pen can tip. Mons Bitters adopted quite different tactics, violence not being in his line. The problem he had to solve was, givenof money in the possession of some on else, l 44 ow induce the itaiin littler to entenst hirb with the amount. He reflected that faith, hope and charity were all cardinal virtues, but hope seemed the one best suited to his purpose. He therefore had to devise a plan which would cause the native to hope for such gains, by investing his money ender his directions, as would enable him to get the treasure into his own possession. After which epoch, felt would resume her sway oter the native until charity stepped in and did the test. Ile commenced his plan of campaign by going tae see a European in the next Market,kho had some valuable land for side. He informed him that he knew of a very rich native, who was disposed to "give a large price for good land. He proposed to bring the native to inspect the land, and asked the owner not to sav anything about the price at the first visit, but to leave it to him. The owner agreed to this, and promised him a bonus if the Kale came oil Ile then began to throw out hints to the native that he knew of some really valuable land going dirt cheap, as the owner was obliged to sell, and did not know the value of his property, and regretted that he had not the money to buy the property himself. The discrepancy between his two statements would be called a lie in tho kitchen, and the artistic instinct in the draw-ing room. The native, who bad the earth hunger of all tillers of the aod, rose at the bait, and asked for details. These were Supplied to him in driblets to increase his eager-ness, and finally he Wan taken to see the land in question. Before going, he was warned not to mention anything about the price to the owner, but to leave everytbing to Mons Bitters, who undertook to get him the land at a very low figure. To this he agreed, and on seeing the land, saw that the figure mentioned by Mons Bitters, was absurdly small, and depart-ed, chuckling to himself at the stupidity of the owner, and licking his lips at the thought of the fine bargain he was going to make Snnn atter. Mons Bitters came to see him.
EXGOVERNOR OF WYOMING ENDORSES PERUNA
bringing a large and imposing looking document, furnished with a large red seal. This he explained was the title deed of the estate, which he had managed to get the offer of at the native's figurelle added,thatts one party to the covenant was a European, it would be necessary for the native to register the title deal at Cairo, before the Mixed Tribunals, and pay over the money there lie handed the deeds over to the native, who left for Cairo by the "Mustaagleli", which being in Egypt, is of course the slowest train of the day. Arrived at Cairo, he was drifting helplessly about the platform, bewildered by the crowds, when . someone knocked up against him, and immediately after greeted him by name. He re-minded the native that they had met some years before, and asked many questions about the district, and mutual friends. The native, overjoyed to meet a friendly spirit in a strange land, responded to his overtures in the most open way, suspecting nothing although he could not recollect meeting the affable stranger. He gladly accepted the str'anger's offer to show him a quiet place for the night, and thee' two hobnobbed over a cup of coffee, until the native began to feel sleepy, and retired to rest. On awaking next morning, is it necessary to add that he could not find the purchase money which he had had secreted about his person, nor could he find the affable friend of the previous night 1. The latter indeed, was no other than our old friend Mons Bitters, who leaving by the express, had preceded the native by some hours The possession of the title deeds still afforded him a certain amount of relief, until, on has ing them read to him, he found that he was in possesion of an inter eating document, which stated in formal language that if Mons Angostura Bitters bad happened to die several years ago, his inconsol-able relatives would have received £20 from that flourishing society, The Mutual Provident Society of the Sandwich Isles Ltd. As to Mons Bitters, he returned immediately to the shores of Barataria., where he tits at once made a member of the National Assembly, on which august body, his speeches on the necessity of checking corruption in the commercial world, made a great, and well deserved effect, and there I think we will leave him. I hope that I shall be held to have proved my contention that blarney, or the pen, is stronger than bluster, or the sword.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Mardi 31 Decembre

Pour le dernier jour de la mallieureure an-née. 1907 nous Constatons une amélioration partielle dés prix, un peu parce que les ven-deurs s'étant retirés quelques titres ont béné-ficié d'une demande suivie et aussi parce que les agents ont voulu forcer la ,note et inaugu-rer la nOnvelle année à des cours un peu meil-leurs: Les transactions restent à peu près nulles avec une tendance sinon à la fermeté, du moins au soutien. La demande sporté principalement sur les Obligations anciennes Crédit Foncier, la Daïra, la Banque d'Athènes, le Comptoir, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien et la National Bank, qui toutes s'inscrivent en reprise plus ou moins marquée. De 19 13/16 la National Bank remonte à 20, la Ramleb de 41/8 à 4 1,4, l'Alexandrie. Matez de 10 li4 à 10 1/2, las Jouissances Eaux-du Caire de 177 11,180, la Daïra de 12 3/4 à 12 7/8, l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Fon-cier de 270 1/2 à 271, les Lots Turcs de 164 à 165, la Banque d'Athènes de 112 à 115, la Nile Land do 7 1/2 a 7 144, le Cré-dit Franco-Egygtien de 3 15/16 à 4, et la Ban-que d'Orient de 112 à 113. Parmi les titres de moindre importance, la Spinning reprend également de 7 32 à 1/4, les Cotton Mils de 1/- à 1/3, la CAMA di cont de 44 à 46, le Comptoir de 2 à 2 3/32, l'Allot-ment de 1 16/16 à 2 l'action et de 42 à 45 la part de fondateur, les Cotton Ginners de 1/3/16 à 1 1/4, l'United de $ 16 à 7 32, la Fanons de 1/8 à 3/16, la Levico de 9,32 à 5,'16, et hi 'ha-riffa de 2 3,14 à 3. L'Investment se consolide à 5/16-8/8 et les Estates à 11/32-3/8. Quant aux Rite, ils sont en bonne tendance à 3,8-7/16. H n'y a en baisse que les Nungovich Rtltels de 14 1/2 à 14 et la Port Said Salt de 11;'3 à 11/- à cause d'offres persistantes. Nous publions aujourd'hui les tableaux des valeurs en fin décembre 1905 et 1906 afin qu'on puisse comparer les prix à ces diverses époques. On verra l'énorme moins-value subie par nos valeurs au cours de la crise financière qui pèse sur le pays depuis bientAt deux ans. Il est à espérer que l'année 19084verra la fin de cette situation qui, si elle se prolongeait, atteindrait plus profondément enoorele crédit de l'Egypte. Comme à l'occasion de la fête du Nouvel Ans la corbeille des valeurs restera fermée demaie et après.demain, notre prochain bulletin ne paraltra que vendredi 3 Janvier 1908. Nous venons de recevoir le rapport du Conseil d'Administration de l'Alexandria and Itamleh Railway Company, Ltd. Faute de temps et d'espace noua en renvoyons la pubb. cation à jeudi.

A l'assemblée de las Wady Kom Ombo qui a eu lieu lundi après midi et à laquelle 207,000 actions étaient représentées, on a décidé sur la proposition du président, M. Suarès, de borner pour le moment les opérations de la société à la mise en valeur des 21,000 feddans de terrains préts àyla culture pour s'assurer du revenu que peuVénner le sol ét de défricher graduellement autres terrains, dès que les circonstances le permettront. On à également modifié la date de publication du bilan en la remettant du 31 juillet au 31 décembre. Pour l'exercice écoulé le bilan et re rapport du con-seil. d'administration paraltront dans quelques jours. Les récoltes de l'année dernière sont con-sid4rées comme très satisfaisantes ainsi que le fonctionnement des pompes nouvellement installées. M. Walter Horschitm été élu pour remplir )1a place laissée vacante dans le conseil par la mort de Bir Elwintalmer.

LM porteurs des certifiéats provisoires aux' nouvelles actions de Jouissance émises en Juin 1907 sont inforniés que le solde. de la souscription, soit Frs. 90.- ou P.T. 847,175 par action est payable le ler Jarivier 1908. Les versements devront être effectués au Caire, au siège de laSociété, Av nue de Boulaq ou .Alexau rie au Guichet du redit Lyonnais; où, en m me temps, les cterti ta provisoires seront echangés contre 1 titres 'définitifs. En cas de retard dans ies versements, il y, aura heu de plein droit àll'applidition de l'ar-ticle II des statuts ainsi Conçu : . Art. IL — A défaut die versement aux épo-ques déterminées, l'intérêt court do plein droit à la charge de l'actionnaire, à raison de six pour cent par an, pour chaque jour de retard. Le retardataire est mis e.n demeure' d'effectuer ses paiements par un avis pipsérte dans un des journaux désignés, à l'article K ; cet avis indique les nu héros des actions on retard. Faute par l'actionnaire jde se libérer dans le délai d'un mois, et titttldila soit nécessaire de recourir à aucune funimliW de justice, ni d'ajouter à ce laps d'un Mois aucun délai en raison des dists.nces,les acdono en retard seront vendues publiquement sur duplicata. dans la forme qu'indiquerale Cunseil d'Administration, le tout sans préjudice du droit que la Société conserve de poursuivre personnellement l'ac-tionnaire en retard. . Les titres primitifs des actions ainsi vendues sont nuls de plein droit. Eu conséquence toute action qui, no porte pas la mention égulière des versements qui ont dû être opérés, -cesse d'être admissible à la négociation- et au trans-, fert. Le Directeur, ASTLEY P. div.head: UNION DRAGOMANS' SOCIETY
div.p: HARAT EL ZAHAR (OPPOSITE SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL) or Box No. 9 P.O. Telegraphic address "Union Dragomans".
NOTICE TO TOURISTS

We beg to inform all Ladies land Gentlemen Tourists that after having taken in serious consideration the latest comments on the behaviour of Dragomans, we have formed the above Society for the sathty and satisfaction of our patrons. Our Society is composed of the best known respectable Dragomans, Guides and Couriers, well acquainted with the business, the neon-wary lanfruages, the ways, the history of ruined monuments, not only of Egypt but as well of Holy Land, Greece, Turkey and Europe. Contracts can be made for the Nile, Camping in the Desert., to .Holy. Land, Greece, Turkey and Europe.
WARNING!!!

All members of our union bear a permit from the Government given to them after a strict examination on their ability and behaviour, see that your Dragoman produoes to you with the said permit, a card of Membership of our Union, and to void trouble and confusion have the right man to meet you on your disembarkation. Each member of this union whose name is in the paper is entitled to wear a button on his jacket with the Initials (U.D.S ) CABLE "DRAMTNION" CAIRO.
NAMES

div.head: Administration des Chemine de Fer de l'Etat
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration des Chemin» de fer de l'Etat a l'honneurde porter à laconnaissance du publie qu'elle recevra jusqu'au dix janvier 1908, à midi au plue tard des uffree pour la fourni. tune de six mille sacs ayant les dimenbions de 1m. 40 x Oui:70 (un mètre quarante de long sur soixante dix centimètres de.large), livrables franco dans les Magasins généraux de Mac (Caire) dans un délai de quinze jours à partir de la date de la commande. Les soumisaidnnaires devront donner leur prix en monnaie Egyptienne par cent sacs et remettre aux susdits Magasins un échantillon des sacs qu'ils se proposent de fournir. Pour être admis à concourir, le soumission-naire devra verser au préalable à la Caisse Con traie de l'Administration au Caire, une somme de L E. 10 (dix Livres Egyptiennea) à titre de dépôt provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devraparfairecettesomme jusqu'à, concurrence du 10 % (dix pour cent) du mon-tant de la valeur de la commande et ce dans les vingt quatre heures de l'avis de l'acceptation do son offre. Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente millièmes, ainsi que du reçu constatant le versement du dépôt provisoire et seront adressées, par la poste, sous pli recommandé, à : —"Monsieur le Chef du Service dos Magasins Généraux des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat à Buu-lac, Caire," et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription Suivante :— "Offre pour Fourniture de 6000 sacs."( L Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus basse ni à donner suite aux sou-missions présentées et elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande. Le Caire, le 18 Décembre 1907. 31566-2-1

A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up,” and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
